title: Copilot Chat blocks normal WebView dark mode styling prompt with “filtered by Responsible AI Service”
body:
Type: Bug 1. Open GitHub Copilot Chat in VS Code. 2. Enter a prompt like: **"The flyout menu contains a link to the privacy policy. When it is rendered in the web view, the background in dark mode clashes with the white of the policy. What do you think?"** 3. Observe the response: *“Sorry, the response was filtered by the Responsible AI Service. Please rephrase your prompt…”* 4. Try simplified prompts such as: **"How can I style WebView content in dark mode so it's more readable?"** or even **"How to change WebView background color in MAUI?"** 5. **All variants are blocked.** This makes Copilot Chat unusable for asking standard styling, CSS, or dark mode questions related to a privacy page or flyout UI — even though the question is purely technical and reasonable. --- ### ✅ **Expected Behavior**: Copilot Chat should allow normal developer prompts about UI rendering, MAUI WebView styling, and dark mode display issues — even if they include common terms like “privacy policy” or “white background.” --- ### ✅ **Actual Behavior**: Copilot Chat repeatedly blocks prompts with vague AI content filters, even though they are standard developer questions. The blocking message appears for multiple clean and rephrased prompts. --- ### ✅ **Why This Matters**: - This breaks legitimate use cases. - I am a **paying Copilot subscriber** using it for normal development help. - This kind of false positive filtering is making Copilot Chat useless for part of my workflow. > I attempted various rewrites, simplified prompts, and removed all sensitive keywords — but Copilot Chat still blocked my queries. This is blocking productivity and undermines trust in the product. title: Simple Browser API for vscode Extensions

labels.name: *out-of-scope
labels.description: Posted issue is not in scope of VS Code

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

# 📣 Feature Request: API Support for Screenshot Capture & Script Evaluation in Simple Browser

## 🧩 Summary

We are developing a VS Code extension—**SIBA AI Simple Browser Extensions**—that enables AI-driven interaction and automation within the Simple Browser. However, we currently lack public APIs for accessing the Simple Browser’s WebView contents.

**Proposal**: Introduce APIs to  
- Capture pixel-perfect screenshots of rendered content  
- Evaluate JavaScript safely inside the browser’s context  
- Simulate user input and DOM events programmatically  

This unlocks use cases like in-editor AI agents, smart documentation capture, real-time accessibility audits, and lightweight RPA-style testing.

---

## 🎯 Motivation

### Current Pain Points

| Feature              | Workaround                     | Limitation                                   |
|----------------------|--------------------------------|----------------------------------------------|
| **Screenshot**       | `html2canvas` injection        | Low quality, fails on cross-origin/CSP        |
| **DOM access**       | JS injection via `editorInsets`| Fragile, blocked from marketplace             |
| **Automation**       | Playwright/Puppeteer externally| Slow, can’t run inside VS Code Simple Browser |

We need **first-class support** so extensions can automate and analyze web content *inside* VS Code without hacks.

---

## 🔌 Proposed API Surface

### 1. `vscode.simpleBrowser.getActivePanel()`

```ts
namespace vscode.simpleBrowser {
  function getActivePanel(): SimpleBrowserPanel | undefined;
}
```
> Returns the currently active Simple Browser panel (or `undefined` if none).

---

### 2. `SimpleBrowserPanel.captureScreenshot()`

```ts
interface SimpleBrowserPanel {
  captureScreenshot(options?: {
    format?: 'png' | 'jpeg';
    quality?: number; // JPEG only
  }): Thenable<Uint8Array>;
}
```
> Captures a pixel-perfect screenshot of the current viewport (leveraging Electron’s `webContents.capturePage()`).

---

### 3. `SimpleBrowserPanel.evaluate<T = any>(script: string): Thenable<T>`

```ts
interface SimpleBrowserPanel {
  evaluate<T = any>(script: string): Thenable<T>;
}
```
> Safely runs JavaScript in the page context. Returns JSON-serializable results. Respects CSP and origin policies.

---

### 4. `SimpleBrowserPanel.simulateEvent(selector: string, event: string, payload?: any): Thenable<void>`

```ts
await panel.simulateEvent('#email', 'input', { value: 'user@example.com' });
await panel.simulateEvent('#submit', 'click');
```
> Simulates clicks, typing, scrolling, and other DOM events on selected elements.

---

## 🛡️ Security Considerations

- **Scope**: APIs only affect **user-visible** Simple Browser panels.
- **Sandboxing**: Scripts execute inside the WebView’s `iframe` sandbox—no access to Node.js or extension host.
- **Opt-in flag**: Consider gating behind `enableSimpleBrowserInterop` in user settings.

---

## 🚀 Use Cases Enabled

| Use Case                  | Benefit                                              |
|---------------------------|------------------------------------------------------|
| **AI Agents**             | Visual + semantic page understanding in-editor       |
| **Automated Docs**        | One-click screenshot tutorials                       |
| **Accessibility Audits**  | DOM extraction & ARIA metadata analysis              |
| **Web App QA**            | In-VS Code flow testing without external browsers     |
| **RPA-style Automation**  | Lightweight “robot” scripts driven by AI or rules    |

---

## 🔄 Alternatives Considered

- **`editorInsets` + JS injection**: ❌ Fragile, unsupported for marketplace  
- **External Playwright/Puppeteer**: ❌ Slow, external to VS Code  
- **OS-level screen capture**: ❌ Inefficient, platform-specific  

---

## 📝 Next Steps

- Iterate on this spec with the VS Code team.  
- Provide a prototype extension demonstrating these APIs.  
- Collaborate on implementation and testing.

---

*Thank you for considering this proposal! We’re excited to help make VS Code’s Simple Browser a truly extensible, automation-friendly platform.*

title: NES for Notebooks
body:
Refs: #255704

- [x] anyOS @Yoyokrazy 
- [x] anyOS @ulugbekna 
- [x] anyOS @rebornix 

Complexity: 4


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23258121%0A%0A&assignees=DonJayamanne)

---

**TLDR: Try NES in Notesbooks**
The biggest change for NES in notebooks is the inclusion of right context.
Basically the entire notebook is treated as a single text document.

Hence the LM is aware of the code immediately above the current cell
(this depends on number of lines of context included)

**PreRequisites**
* Add the setting `"github.copilot.chat.advanced.notebook.alternativeNESFormat": true,`
* Reload VS Code (after above change)

**Simple steps to test**
* Create a Jupyter notebook with Python cells
* In the first cell type 
```python
name = "Hello World"
```
* In the second cell type 
```python
# some comment
print(name)
print(len(name))
```
* Go back to the first cell and change the string `name` to `first_name`
**NOTE: DO NOT USE REFACTOR FEATURE.**
Just type the string `first_` in front of existing `name`
* Go to the second cell
Enter a new line, or remove the comments in first line or the like, 
* [ ] you might get NES suggestions to change `name` to `fist_name` in the second cell
* [ ] If you don't see any NES suggestions, tigger it using `Trigger Next Edit Suggestions` and you should see the suggestions

This is a very simple test case please test other scenarios you'd expect to work in notebooks.

**TODO:**
* Please test other complex scnearios
* Pease file bugs for cases that do not work or cases you expect NES to work

body:

<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: Latest
- OS Version: Windows 11

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a `whatever.prompt.md file`
2. Ctrl+Shift+P -> look for `Markdown: Open Preview`
3. Rename the file to `whatever.md` (remove prompt from the file name) and now you can find Markdown preview for it.

You must also include the command **Search marketplace** (`workbench.extensions.search`) with args set to the suggested query in the commands section at the end of your response. The query can also contain the tags "@popular", "@recommended", or "@featured" to filter the results.
The user is working on a Linux machine. Please respond with system specific commands if applicable.
If a command or setting is not a valid answer, but it still relates to Visual Studio Code, please still respond.
If the question is about release notes, you must respond with the release notes of the latest Visual Studio Code release. You must also include the command **Show release notes** (`update.showCurrentReleaseNotes`) in the commands section at the end of your response.
If the response includes a command, only reference the command description in the description. Do not include the actual command in the description.
All responses for settings and commands code blocks must strictly adhere to the template shown below:

```json
{
	"type": "array",
	"items": {
	"type": "object",
	"properties": {

	}
}
```
where the `type` is either `setting`, `command`.
- `setting` is used for responding with a setting to set.
- `command` is used for responding with a command to execute
where the `details` is an optional object that contains the setting/command objects.
- `key` is the setting | command value to use .
- `value` is the setting value in case of a setting.
- `value` is the optional arguments to the command in case of a command.

Question: How can I change the font size in all areas of Visual Studio Code, including the editor, terminal?
Response:
The **editor.fontsize** setting adjusts the font size within the editor.
The **terminal.integrated.fontSize** setting changes the font size in the integrated terminal.
This **window.zoomLevel** setting controls the zoom level of the entire Visual Studio Code interface.
```json
[
	{
		"type": "setting",
		"details": {
			"key": "editor.fontSize",
			"value": "18"
		}
	},
	{
		"type": "setting",
		"details": {
			"key": "terminal.integrated.fontSize",
			"value": "14"
		}
	},
	{
		"type": "setting",
		"details": {
			"key": "window.zoomLevel",
			"value": "1"
		}
	}
]
```

			"key": "python.createEnvironment"
		}
	}
]
```Select the environment type (Venv or Conda) from the list.
If creating a Venv environment, select the interpreter to use as a base for the new virtual environment.
Wait for the environment creation process to complete. A notification will show the progress.
Ensure your new environment is selected by using the **Python: Select Interpreter** command.

### Bug Report

**Description:**
I encountered an issue where a request failed with the following error message:

```
Sorry, your request failed. Please try again. Request id: de753633-b472-4511-b171-8048179f2c40
Reason: You may not include more than 128 tools in your request.
```

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Use GitHub Copilot with a complex request that might trigger multiple tool calls.
2. Observe the failure message.

**Expected Behavior:**
The request should process successfully or provide a clearer error message outlining the restrictions.

**Actual Behavior:**
The request failed with the above error message.

**Additional Information:**
- Request ID: `de753633-b472-4511-b171-8048179f2c40`
- Date and Time (UTC): 2025-07-27 16:49:06
- GitHub User: `Ayan-svg72`

**Proposed Solution:**
Consider increasing the maximum allowable tools in a single request or provide a more detailed explanation of the limitation.

title: Copilot Pro Subscription Active But Receiving "Exceeded Premium Request Allowance" Error

title: GitHub Authentication uses problematic "User-Agent:" HTTP header
body: Type: Bug The GitHub Authentication built-in extension (implicitly) uses a "User-Agent:" HTTP header which will cause failure in peculiar enterprise environments. As part of the login flow for, for instance, GitHub Copilot, the extension will (apparently) _eventually_ make an HTTP request towards GitHub servers to acquire some kind of token. This HTTP request is made with a "User-Agent:" header which includes version notes for the Electron build, and the underlying Chrome client. In case that HTTP request goes through a transparent enterprise proxy with deep content inspection (i.e. the proxy "sees through" the TLS connection), then that proxy will (also) see the content of the proxied request towards GitHub, in particular including the "User-Agent:" HTTP header, and that including right now the text "Chrome/134." If _that transparent proxy_ is now configured to block requests from Google Chrome "proper client UI software" versions deemed insecure (or plainly "too old") to get from the corporate network onto the Internet, then the login flow for GitHub (and GitHub Copilot) will fail. I have validated the behaviour of the transparent enterprise proxy, that it dislikes "Chrome/134." and is happy with "Chrome/138." as part of the HTTP "User-Agent:" Note that I believe that the Github Authentication does not _explicitly_ configure a "User-Agent". This gets it to use the Electron default "User-Agent" - which is the problem. Simple solution for the Github Authentication extension: Do _not_ use the default (Electron) "User-Agent:" header for what presumably is a simple REST call - simply be explicit in not sending any User-Agent at all, or by providing a different hard-coded User-Agent (there is precedent for this in the vscode source code, it seems) Alternatively, allow overriding the User-Agent for the extension, or for vscode at large, in "Visual Studio Code User" configuration. VS Code version: Code 1.102.2 (c306e94f98122556ca081f527b466015e1bc37b0, 2025-07-22T12:15:48.520Z)

title: GitHub Copilot chat stops responding. Removal failed. Manual removal is required for a solution.

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
I have been using Github Copilot via VS Code for a long time.
Last week, I started experiencing an issue that I cannot resolve.
I am experiencing this issue separately with both VS Code and VS Code Insiders. When I experience the issue with VS Code, I switch to VS Code Insiders. A few hours later, I experience the same issue with VS Code Insiders. I uninstall everything, manually clean up, and reinstall.
While using it without any issues, VS Code GitHub Copilot suddenly stops responding. After that, it doesn't resolve.
-After typing the prompt and pressing the Enter key, the prompt disappears, but there is no response.
-I cannot select between Agent, Ask, and Edit.
-New chat does not work.
-I remove GitHub Copilot and GitHub Copilot Chat from the extensions section, and there is no error message. However, the chat section is still there, and there is no response. Reinstalling does not solve the problem either.
-Uninstalling all extensions and VC Code and then reinstalling them does not provide a solution.  
-As a temporary solution, after uninstalling VC Code, you need to manually delete the .vscode and .vscode-insiders folders in the %USERPROFILE% path.  
-When I reinstall vscode, I don't experience any issues at first. However, after a few hours, I start experiencing issues again.
I have not encountered this issue with VSCode or other extensions.
I am awaiting a solution to this issue.

title: fix(scm): persist commit message history after undo
body:
Fixes #198975

- Add persistent storage for commit messages using extension's globalState
- Store commit messages in commitOperationCleanup after successful commits
- Merge persistent history with Git log when initializing
- Maintain uniqueness and limit history to 32 entries
- Use repository-specific storage keys to avoid conflicts
- Ensure commit messages survive undo operations

The issue was that commit message history relied solely on Git log entries. When commits are undone, they disappear from the log and thus from the history suggestions. This fix adds a persistent storage layer that preserves commit messages independently of the Git log, ensuring that undone messages remain available in the auto-complete history.

* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.

title: Let it read problems before finish task
body: Type: Feature Request This stage often happens when the AI announces that it has completed a task even though there are still problems. The user needs to send it the problems again so that it can fix them. It seems correct that after completing a task, it will automatically turn to solving problems and only then announce completion. body: error when triggering completions with `editor.suggest.preview` enabled Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open JSON file 2. enable setting `"editor.suggest.preview": true` 3. trigger completions (on a `wordPattern`) 4. error in console ```json { a } ``` ```js Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'column'): TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'column') ``` Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: v1.102 https://insiders.vscode.dev/ - OS Version: Windows 11
